canonical_rel_desc: Indicates the metallurgical/microstructural phase type (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic, or mixed) that characterizes a metal or alloy under specified conditions.
Indicates that a microstructure, damage mechanism, process, or product phase occurs in or is present within a given material or alloy family.
Indicates that two material classes are conceptually related because they can exhibit similar or analogous microstructural features under certain conditions.
Indicates that two materials or chemicals can serve the same functional role in a given application and may be substituted for one another.
Indicates that the subject is a broader class that includes the object as one of its more specific subtypes or categories.
Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
Indicates that an alloy or material contains a given chemical element as part of its intentional alloy composition.
Subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion or degradation mechanism under certain conditions.
Subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to the resistance of a material system against a specified corrosion or degradation mechanism.
Indicates that two concepts are presented as peer categories or sections within the same classification or list (e.g., in a document), without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependency.
A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).
A process or transformation leads to the formation of a specific microstructural constituent or feature within a material (e.g., graphite nodules, carbides, precipitates).
Subject inhibits or effectively eliminates the occurrence of the specified degradation or metallurgical process under the stated conditions.
